awd_titl_txt: CRII: CHS: Knowing and Creating: Implications of Increased Information Availability During the Design Process
awd_abstract_narration:
Developing creative products is a key software engineering problem for companies that want to distinguish themselves from similar products in the market.  Relatively little is known, however, about how software development teams in the early stages of design use relevant information such as customer behavior and competing products to generate creative ideas for product requirements, nor how different kinds of information might affect their creativity. This project will study how expert software designers engage with design information in the early stages of software development to develop an "Information Archetypes Framework" that characterizes design information and its influence on design creativity.  This framework will be validated through studying the performance of student design teams that are given different types of information to support product brainstorming activities.  In addition to improving understanding of design creativity and cognition from a research perspective, the project team will conduct collaborative workshops with local software development and startup companies to discuss how to effectively navigate complex information to enhance their competitiveness.  The project will also have significant educational impacts through training student researchers, informing the design of innovation-enhancing activities for software engineering students, the development of a broader curriculum on innovation in information technology, and supporting outreach through immersive summer programming workshops aimed at increasing middle school girls' knowledge and interest in STEM and design-related careers.

The research component of the project has two main elements.  The first aims to expand on an initial version of the Information Archetypes Framework that characterizes the source, abstractness, and generality of information, as well as team styles for problem solving and sharing information.  To do this, expert software designers will be asked to attend a design session and given a short design problem along with carefully crafted pieces of information that are relevant to the problem domain and correspond to the dimensions identified in the current version of the framework.  The project team will ask each designer to organize the information and explain how they made judgments about the relatedness and potential usefulness of the different pieces of information for design, using a combination of quantitative analysis of the similarity judgments and qualitative analysis of interview responses to revise the framework.  The impact of the revised framework on design creativity will then be investigated by developing a similar design problem for an introductory design class in an information technology innovation program, giving each student team a unique set of relevant information corresponding to each type of information identified in the revised framework.  The project team will use a protocol analysis of each team's interactions to analyze how these differences in available information affect communicative content and processes, along with an existing framework for measuring the novelty and quality of generated ideas in order to link differences in available information to the teams' design outputs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The studies conducted for this project spanned both design experts who currently practice in technical design disciplines such as software and engineering design, and novice designers who are design students in higher education settings. The results of these studies provided an in-depth understanding of the types of information structuring strategies used by experts to process and leverage large amounts of information to solve complex design problems. This knowledge is used as a way to conceptualize the cognitive processes that are employed by experts during this process. Most notably, we present 3 information structuring methods that build upon one another and increase in sophistication and complexity: Clusters, Relations, and Nests. This finding provides evidence that expertise plays a role in the effectiveness of knowledge structures employed during problem solving.

The result of this work is directly transferable to design education through exploring the different structuring strategies and their impact on the design process and outcomes. Research extending the findings from expert designers to student design teams showed that there are significant temporal changes in how design teams developed and communicated these complex design information networks across a team project. This work showed that design novices at first increase the similarities in their knowledge structures with their team members, but these similarities deviate towards the end of the project, as a final deliverable is being developed. One possible explanation for this evolution of shared knowledge structures in novice design teams is that teams begin delegating more and more of the design project tasks towards the end of the project when the work becomes more challenging and time consuming. Thus, these students begin understanding the project differently depending on their ascribed roles in a project and their priorities. Results from studies investigating information richness in inspirational stimuli and ideas generated by students show that the archetypal information stimuli presented prior to ideation has some influence on design outcomes. Specifically, showing images with higher densities of information actually reduced the variety of features explored in idea generated by students, indicating that students may be fixating on visually salient features found in stimuli, limiting their creativity during that activity. On the other hand, the more information dense their sketches were, the worse quality these ideas were, indicating that more information included in a design does not necessarily lead to better outcomes.

The project deals with fundamental human processes such as creation, problem solving, and sense making. While the context of these activities is in technical domains such as engineering design, software design, and human-centered computing, increasing our understanding of these fundamental processes allow us to enhance our capacity for innovation, technological advancement, and social change. By deconstructing the often mystified process of creativity and design and systematically investigating the process of addressing large, ill-structured problems, this research also seeks to open up access to this knowledge and enhance the profession. At a fundamental level, designers make decisions about who to include in their design, how to produce "good" designs that positively impact society, and many of the methods and theories that are used in practice are called into question as part of this work. Follow-up investigation of the results of both these research threads show that frameworks from philosophy typically underlie these decisions since designers are often put in the position to make judgements about how to use available resources to benefit specific groups of individuals. This discourse moves the field of technical design forward to integrate philosophical theories and frameworks into assessments of design outcomes and restructuring current design methods to integrate issues of ethics and justice into how we practice design.
